Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Synthesis and Fundamental Organometallic Reactivity of Low-Valent Uranium Alkyls
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this CAREER Award, the Chemistry Synthesis program is supporting the research of Professor Suzanne Bart at Purdue University. In this project, Professor Bart will focus on the synthesis, characterization, and reactivity of reduced uranium complexes for small molecule activation. The planned research will test the hypothesis that low-valent uranium alkyls are useful synthons for elusive uranium targets. Experiments will be carried out to 1) obtain a family of uranium(III) alkyls with a variety of ancillary ligands, 2) understand under what conditions uranium can undergo two electron processes, similar to late transition metals, including reductive elimination, oxidative addition, and migratory insertion, 3) explore the utility of uranium alkyls for multiple bond formation. The planned research includes synthetic methods, spectroscopic analysis, and computational approaches to fully understand the reactivity of these compounds.

In terms of the educational plan, Professor Suzanne Bart will continue and expand her initiative to increase the population of women among college age science majors with her ChemTeens conference (formerly "High School Day on Campus for Girls"). Through this program, junior and senior female students are invited to interact with leading female faculty in the chemical sciences at Purdue to learn about careers, college majors, and the benefits and challenges of a career in the sciences. At this event, participants also make connections with current undergraduate and graduate students who can serve as mentors and take the intimidation out of a major in science as the participants begin their college careers. Professor Bart will also participate in a program aimed at high school teachers in Indiana. Through this program, the high school teachers could perform and videotape in Professor Bart's laboratory those demonstrations not possible in their own classrooms. These demonstrations help to highlight the importance of rare earth and actinide elements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funding of this CAREER award supported the research program of Prof. Suzanne Bart at Purdue University. The foundation of our research is the synthesis and characterization of low-valent uranium alkyls, with our latest efforts on understanding how these species participate in fundamental organometallic reactions.  We have been striving to understand how these systems compare and contrast with their popular transition metal counterparts, with an emphasis placed on understanding redox capabilities of these organouranium molecules. Over the last five years of funded work, we have published fourteen manuscripts in total and have one under consideration for a total of fifteen for the funding period.

The principal investigator’s laboratory is working to understand the synthesis, characterization, and reactivity of reduced uranium complexes for small molecule activation.  Initial findings have established the great chemical potential of uranium-carbon bonds, where uranium exists in the +3 and +4 oxidation states, and taught us how to effectively work with this electron-rich metal. During the lifetime of the grant, 1) we synthesized and characterized a family of uranium(III) alkyls with a variety of ancillary ligands, 2) we studied how stable these uranium-carbon bonds are as well as how they react with other small molecules, 3) we manipulated the redox chemistry of uraninum to make it accomplish two electron processes, similar to late transition metals, including reductive elimination, oxidative addition, and migratory insertion, 4) we explored how to use these uranium-carbon bonds to generate new uranium-element double and triple bonds.

The work performed here taught students how to work safely with radioactive compounds in a laboratory setting.  Students learned synthetic methods, spectroscopic analysis, and computational approaches to fully understand the bonding and reactivity of these compounds.  Students also learned the use of common laboratory equipment used in air- and moisture-sensitive training, including the use of gloveboxes, Schlenk lines, solvent purification systems, compressed gas cylinders, and vacuum pumps. Student learned to use, maintain, and share equipment to accomplish project goals. Students work was disseminated in journals in the field, as well as at local and international conferences.

During the project period, Prof. Bart integrated organometallic chemistry and uses and properties of the f-block elements into the program of study of high school, college, and graduate students. This is helping to remedy the problem that elements in the bottom of the periodic table are typically overlooked in core undergraduate curricula. She continued and expand her initiative to increase the population of women among college age science majors with her ChemTeens conference. Through this program, junior and senior girls were invited to interact with leading female faculty in the chemical sciences at Purdue to learn about careers, college majors, and the benefits and challenges of a career in the sciences. At this event, participants also made connections with current undergraduate and graduate students who can serve as mentors and take the intimidation out of a major in science as the participants begin their college careers. Second, Prof. Bart participated in a workshop aimed at high school educators in Indiana.  These teachers worked in her research lab, performing and videotaping demonstrations not possible in their own classrooms due to toxic materials, budgetary restrictions, and time constraints. Her participation results in the dissemination of our research throughout the state, reaching underrepresented groups and a wide range of socioeconomic classes.  Third, Dr. Bart also participated in local activities, including being a faculty mentor for Iota Sigma Pi, a national chemistry women's honor society, and participating in College Mentors for Kids, a program that helps show children what higher education can do for them. Fourth, Prof. Bart also participated in ACS Project SEED, which is a chance for economically disadvantaged high school students to spend a summer doing research in the lab of a faculty member.  Dr. Bart has hosted three students through this program. Overall, cultivating and sharing excitement for this type of science is important in order to maintain a diverse number of chemists trained in handling rare earth and actinide elements for future generations. Understanding how to handle and take advantage of the basic chemistry of these elements is essential for issues pertaining to nuclear energy, including but not limited to fuel generation, spent nuclear fuel processing, and environmental remediation.


Last Modified: 11/21/2017
Modified by: Suzanne C Bart
